questions.text: Hemodialysis is used in all the poisoning except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hemodialysis is a treatment to filter wastes and water from the blood, as the kidneys do when they were healthy. Hemodialysis helps control blood pressure and balance important minerals, such as potassium, sodium, and calcium, in blood.

Explanation of other options:

Barbiturates (Option B): Hemodialysis is effective, especially in long-acting types or severe overdose.

Alcohol (Option C): Hemodialysis is beneficial in methanol, ethanol, and isopropanol toxicity.

Cocaine (Option D): Although not routinely dialyzed, in some severe cases (especially with renal compromise), dialysis may still be part of supportive care—but not contraindicated like kerosene.

Key Takeaway:

Hemodialysis is not useful in kerosene poisoning due to poor dialyzability and risk of aspiration as the main clinical issue.

questions.text: A dead body is having cadaveric lividity of bluish green colour. The most likely cause of death is by poisoning due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of other options:

Hydrocyanic acid (Option A): Causes bright red or pink hypostasis due to formation of cyanohemoglobin.

Oleander (Option C): A cardiac glycoside; no characteristic discoloration-death is usually due to arrhythmia.

Sodium nitrite (Option D): Produces chocolate-brown postmortem staining due to methemoglobinemia.

Key Takeaway:

Bluish-green cadaveric lividity is a strong indicator of hydrogen sulphide poisoning, often accompanied by a characteristic rotten egg odor.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is found unresponsive near a chemical warehouse and brought dead to the emergency department. During the medicolegal autopsy, the forensic expert notes reddish-brown discoloration of hypostasis and minor abrasions on the upper limbs. Based on these findings, which of the following poisons is most likely responsible for the observed postmortem lividity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of other options:

Carbon monoxide (Option B): Causes cherry red hypostasis due to carboxyhemoglobin formation.

Cyanides (Option C): Lead to bright red hypostasis due to oxygen-saturated hemoglobin (OxyHb).

Hydrogen sulphide (Option D): Produces bluish-green discoloration due to sulphemoglobin formation.

Key Takeaway:

 Reddish-brown postmortem staining is classically seen in poisoning due to nitrites or aniline, and is linked to methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Fishy like smell can be detected in poisoning with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

AlPhos is the trade name of aluminium phosphide which give rise to fishy/musty odour. Sometimes it also give rise to garlicky odour.

Aluminium phosphide poisoning is poisoning that occurs as a result of excessive exposure to aluminium phosphide (AlP), which is readily available as a fumigant for stored cereal grains and sold under various brand names such as AlPhos, QuickPhos, SAL PHOS and CELPHOS etc.

Explanation of other options:

Copper (Option A): Associated with a metallic taste and greenish vomitus-no characteristic fishy smell.

Paraldehyde (Option B): Produces a fruity or acetaldehyde-like odor-not fishy.

Opium (Option C): Has a strong, characteristic acrid smell-not described as fishy or musty.

Key Takeaway:

Fishy or garlicky odor from a dead body strongly suggests aluminium phosphide (AlPhos) poisoning.

questions.text: A postmortem room receives four dead bodies, each suspected to have died of poisoning. On examination, the following distinct odors were noted:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fishy smell → Aluminium phosphide (AlPhos), due to phosphine gas
  • Bitter almond → Cyanide (Prussic acid)
  • Rotten egg → H2S, Disulfiram, Carbon disulphide
  • Garlicky smell → Arsenic, phosphorus, thallium

questions.text: Smell of burnt rope due to poisoning with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The smell of burnt rope is a distinctive feature of cannabis (marijuana) when it is smoked.

  • Cannabis contains tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), and when burnt, it produces a strong, pungent odour often compared to burnt rope.
  • This smell is commonly recognized during forensic investigations or police raids involving illegal drug use.
  • It can linger on clothing and surroundings, serving as a forensic clue.

Explanation of other options:

Aluminium phosphide (Option A): Produces a garlic or rotten fish-like odour due to release of phosphine gas.

Arsenic (Option C): Has a mild garlic smell, especially in trioxide form.

Cyanide (Option D): Gives off a bitter almond smell; however, not all individuals can perceive it due to genetic anosmia.

questions.text: Shoe polish-like smell is found in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrobenzene poisoning is associated with a distinctive shoe polish-like odor, which serves as an important diagnostic clue in forensic toxicology. It is commonly found in shoe polish, solvents, and industrial chemicals.

Nitrobenzene can cause:

  • Cyanosis due to methemoglobinemia
  • Headache, dizziness, and CNS depression
  • Hemolysis in severe cases

Explanation of other options:

Mercaptans (Option A): Produce a foul, rotten cabbage-like odor—not similar to shoe polish.

Camphor (Option B): Has a strong mothball or medicinal odor.

Paraldehyde (Option C): Produces an acrid or pear-like smell—not shoe polish-like.

Key Takeaway:

Shoe polish-like smell is characteristic of Nitrobenzene poisoning.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is found unresponsive at home with an empty bottle of hypnotic medication nearby. Gastric lavage is performed, and on endoscopy, the gastric mucosa appears bluish in color. Which of the following poisons is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bluish discoloration of the gastric mucosa is a classic finding in Amytal sodium (a barbiturate) poisoning. It results from deposition and chemical interaction of the drug with the mucosa. Amytal (amobarbital) is a short-acting barbiturate that, in overdose, leads to CNS depression, respiratory failure, and sometimes bluish staining of gastric contents and mucosa.

This discoloration is a helpful diagnostic postmortem clue in suspected barbiturate overdose cases.

Explanation of other options:

Lead (Option A): Causes bluish-black Burtonian line over gums—not gastric mucosal discoloration.

Cadmium (Option B): Leads to gastroenteritis and nephrotoxicity, but not blue gastric mucosa.

Arsenic (Option D): Typically causes hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, not bluish mucosa.

Key Takeaway:

Amytal sodium poisoning causes characteristic bluish discoloration of gastric mucosa.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting, altered sensorium, and shallow breathing. On examination, pupils were found to be constricted (miosis). Which of the following poisons is least likely to cause this pupillary finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Miosis (pinpoint pupil) is a classic sign seen in several types of poisoning, especially those that stimulate the parasympathetic system or depress the central nervous system.

  • Opium (opioids) causes intense miosis due to its direct depressant effect on the midbrain.
  • Organophosphorus compounds (OPC) increase acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, leading to miosis.
  • Phenol, though primarily a corrosive, may also cause CNS depression and miosis.
  • Paracetamol, however, does not affect pupil size. It primarily causes hepatic necrosis, and CNS signs like altered mental status, but not miosis.

Explanation of other options:

Opium (Option B): Classic cause of pinpoint pupils due to CNS depressant action.

Phenol (Option C): Can cause miosis along with corrosive effects and CNS toxicity.

OPC (Option D): Causes miosis by overstimulation of parasympathetic nervous system.

Key Takeaway:
Paracetamol toxicity does not present with miosis, unlike opioids, OPC, or phenol poisoning.
